column4: I just want to make a not to all ubuntu.  This is the dumbest thing I have ever seen in an installer.
if you've got no spare harddrive space, how do you intend to install anything, regardless of installer?
unless ubuntu has grown past 12 gigs over night. shouldn't be a problem to install to /
now I'm confused. If you know which partition you want to use, why not just point the installer in the right direction and go get a drink?
I should beable to click a box that says "i dont' give a damn, install without formatting"
because it wants to format the partition
so the problem is? It needs to be empty to install into, yes?
i moved evertyhing around and now it wants to format /,  when all there is on there is /backup
you just dont' want old files to be in teh file system. Which they aren't, all there is, is /backup
is /backup another partition, or just a set of files? If files, they're going to get nuked by the installer. If another partition, who cares?
did you just jump in the middle?
the problem is that EXACTLY.  I don't want to format the /.  I need to install over what is there
I must have, because I feel like I'm missing something odd about your setup
so, your / is already in use, and you're trying to convince the installer to somehow install around the stuff that's there?

recap,  other partitions are full, I have 12 gigs free on a empty file system (except /backup)  there will be no conflicts with the inistaller. It _should_ beable to install without formating.  Every other distro will let you do this.  I'm trying to recover the system.
what good is an installer if it can't do the most simple of recovery tasks.
try the alternate CD installer, if you haven't already. It's the old-fashioned one, uglier but with a few features that haven't made it into the Desktop live installer so far.
